results.title: Indian cooking, Parsi style
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look ‘n’ Cook”.
The Parsi community originated 1,353 years ago, when a small group of people migrated from ancient Persia to India. Today there are hardly 100,000 members of this community in existence. The secrets of their culinary art - the ingredients and style of their cooking - are revealed in this program.

results.title: Not just a number
results.creator_credit: Rob Richardson, Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and Shalagh McCarthy
results.brief_description: A three part documentary examining industrial democracy in Australia: 1) Job redesign. Demonstrates how employees exercise decision-making, responsibility and initiative in their private lives and contracts with the usual workplace situation where most decisions are made by management. 2) Better managers. Shows a factory owned and operated by the workers providing a working example of successful worker participation and industrial democracy. 3) Is it a con? Examines unsuccessful industrial democracy initiatives where only the semblance of power has been transferred to the workers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Richardson, Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and Shalagh McCarthy

results.title: A Future without frontiers
results.creator_credit: Geo Tapparelli, Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration and Carlo di Carlo
results.brief_description: Produced to commemorate the twenty year of ICEM’s existence, this film aims to highlight one of the fundamental human rights - the freedom of movement - and to demonstrates at the same time that through well-planned migration an effective contribution can be made to people looking for better opportunities as well as to countries overseas to strengthen their economic position for further development. Looks at the various programmes carried out by ICEM in the last twenty years and projects some expected future problems of people and their movement in the world.

results.title: Princess of the Blood robes costume
results.credit_line:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric
results.brief_description: This costume from The Last Emperor enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, a sense that’s reinforced by 9,500 extras who appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.description:
From seller: A Princess of the Blood gown and overrobe from the 1987 multi Oscar-winning historical drama The Last Emperor. These women can be seen on several occasions throughout the movie, when PuYi chooses his secondary consort, and at PuYi’s wedding to the Empress. This stunning and elaborate costume consists of a full-length gown of printed red rayon satin, overprinted with dragon robe motif, similarly printed sleeveless overrobe. Also included is a black satin headband with gold filigree buttons (some have been lost over the years) and a string of glass beads and polished stones that hang down the chest, and a cream quilted cotton under robe.
It comes from the private collection of renowned producer Jeremy Thomas (who single handedly raised the $25million budget for the movie) and was archived after filming completed until only recently, when the Prop Store was proud to assist in sorting and cataloguing the incredible inventory under the guidance and in collaboration with Oscar-winning Costume Designer, Jim Acheson.
description_for_label: Colour had arrived in cinema when The Last Emperor (1987) was released but its use in costume and cinematography was Oscar-winning. The film follows Pu Yi’s transition from the last emperor of China to ordinary citizen and colour is fundamental to his journey. Deep crimson and orange hues capture both the majesty and innocence of his childhood in the Forbidden City, while grey saturates moments in jail later in life. This costume by James Acheson enlivens the Imperial court with rich reds that bring grandeur to the screen, further reinforced by 9,500 extras that appear to be draped in delicately embroidered silk thanks to screen-printed rayon.
results.credit_line_for_label:
The Last Emperor, Italy / France, 1987
Designed by James Acheson
Silk screened rayon fabric

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 - Indigo
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Antartica, Future, Wake up Return 2 Heart, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Air Fiction (Andy Taylor), Steve Law (Zen Paradox), Tom Cia, Derek ‘Chill’ Shiel and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: When deaf minds travel
results.brief_description: Much is written and discussed about the mental health challenges for the deaf community, but rarely do we hear from those directly dealing with these challenges. This project was produced in partnership with VicDeaf.
results.description: Much is written and discussed about the mental health challenges for the deaf community, but rarely do we hear from those directly dealing with these challenges. This project was produced in partnership with VicDeaf.

results.title: GTA 6 in real life
results.brief_description: From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers quests as if in a fantasy game – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times and endlessly shared.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have in-built features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers side quests as if in GTA (embedded below) – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times, but there are many versions out there. This TikTok from user @bryteosky features dialogue, sound effects, cinematic cut scenes, graphic overlays and an impressively large cast to further anchor reality to the game.
description_for_label: From TikToks of in-game successes (and failures) to live Twitch streams, social media and videogames are perfectly matched. Modern consoles often have built-in features that let users easily record their play to share online, but this video isn’t that. It looks like leaked footage of Grand Theft Auto 6’s new graphics, but it’s a real-world video mimicking the series’ old-school movements, gestures and streetscapes. It’s like digital cosplay and reflects a larger trend of social users recreating game worlds in real life – like giving strangers quests as if in a fantasy game – which highlights the blurring of online and offline life. It’s been viewed over 40m times and endlessly shared.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Heidi Halloween
results.brief_description: Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit, and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm?
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm?
description_for_label: Heidi Klum is known for her dedication to halloween costumes, having previously dressed as the ogre version of Fiona from Shrek, Jessica Rabbit and even an alien science experiment gone wrong. In 2022 she outdid herself, dressing in full-body prosthetics to party as an earthworm, while husband Tom Kaulitz dressed as a fisherman. The committed costume set social media abuzz as the internet considered that Klum finally had a concrete answer to the age-old question: would you still love me if I was a worm? More so, Klum’s elaborate costumes also pay homage to the movie-making magic of prosthetics and make-up.
